Flow is that "zone" that we all strive to achieve in any exercise that we undertake. In a state of "Flow," your creativity is un-inhibited and you are completely enraptured in the "here and now" -- with notions of time and space completely being altered in your consciousness. For example, if you're an artist, classical musician, a novelist, a worl-class surgeon, or even a sports-enthusiast of any kind -- then you'll appreciate Flow and will relate to the theories advanced in this incredibly expanisve book that cover wide-ranging philosophical/pychological theories. Whatever your profession, you can find a golen nugget in this book and find the inspiration to make life-altering changes. Over and above "Flow", the author is concerned with human nature and what ultimately makes people happy. Going back to Aristotilean and Neo-platonic concepts, he traces the roots of what is at the heart of much of discontent in our society and what experiences really stand out as positively contributing to overall happiness. Obviously, Flow is seamlessly infused as an over-arching principle when all of this is discussed. Check out other books by this author that also examine Flow from different vantage points and examine the nexus between Flow and creativity. If you're into understanding the fundamentals of human nature, what makes our consiousness unique, and are obssessed with happiness (like I am) -- then this is the book for you! Highly recommended.

This presents some interesting ideas that are almost self-evident when someone bothers pointing them out explicitly. These often get overlooked and so are worth examining deliberately, though I'm not convinced that the book does a particularly good job of this. Small quibbles first: some conclusions the author draws from stats early in the book are sloppy at best; there is some kind of odd hangup about communism. A bigger issue is that, while the author lays out seemingly clear-cut requirements for flow to occur, his actual determination of what constitutes a "flow activity" appears arbitrary. I think this is because context plays an important role in the determination--there's more to this than the simplistic set of criteria now quoted everywhere. For instance, counting cracks in the ceiling might be a flow activity for a political prisoner to help her endure incarceration, but watching reality TV doesn't encourage flow in the average person. On an objective basis, neither activity is particularly productive or enjoyable. More tellingly, both can be tailored to meet the requirements for flow. Context is what might make one activity more fulfilling than the other in this example. The book lists many contexts that facilitate flow activities, but does not explain how these contexts come to be so special, nor describe any universal characteristics by which these contexts can be recognized, and thus leveraged.

One should become sceptical, when at the very beginning of a book, the author explains to have a tremendous scientific background but for the purpose of making his findings accessible for the masses, he would exclude it from the text at hand. The first 20 percent or so do actually contain some interesting information that help one understand the concept of flow (pleasure vs. enjoyment), its psychological basis (order in consiousness), its prerequisites (clear goals, skills matching challenges, immediate feedback, etc.), the role of attention, and the consequences of it all (a more "complex" personality). This all sounds very nice and clear and scientific but in the end, is not much more than laymen philosophy. This becomes clearer and clearer in chapter 5, when the Csikszenmihalyi (Will I ever be able to write or say that name with forgetting an 'z' or 't' here and there?) starts giving examples of what cool things people can do when being in flow. Plain and boring, the book continues to give general advice on things like how to raise one's children or keep a relationship alive. Everything Csitszentmizhaliy (wrongly spelled, again..) ever considered in his life he presents the reader as an outcome of his claimed 25 years in research. Disappointing.

Rambling, dry, dense book and I think it is easier to find meaning of life than making sense of some sections of this book. There is definitely some value in the core message of the book namely importance of setting appropriate goals and value of quick feedback. Both are necessary to achieve "optimal" experience. However there definitely is no need to fill 240 pages with orientalist metaphysical musings to communicate this message. The author also goes gun-ho on boredom, watching TV etc. and talks about how to set goals to make walking enjoyable. Needless to say I found these discussions exasperating. I think the book is just a different version of "Who moved my cheese?", where we just have to be like mice increasing productivity and setting goals but never stop to think about the system. If you stop to think about the bigger picture about government its responsibilities you are a failure(not a autotelic personality). Inspite of this I persevered and finished the book for what reason God only knows. My suggestion, skip the book and read a summary like this one.

Depending upon the kind of reads that i have been through (The secret, The monk who sold his ferrari, The alchemist and other hyped reads), i had developed a repulsion for self motivating books. All in all, they talk of the same thing in one way or the other but this book is quite different. First of all, it doesn't assert self motivation. It deals with raw psychology along with facts and examples woven so perfectly that you will feel yourself a bit learned after reading a few pages. It deals at the primal level of thoughts, its process and the whole structure of it...; not just that, it also talks of how each thought makes us "feel". The best thing about this book is its tempo. The minute it starts giving you the details..it also gives the reader a quick glance at the bigger picture in no seconds. Too much feel or too much knowledge gets boring in a book not consisting of fiction. The mind wanders and we start losing the plot. If you are looking for some feel-alongwith-knowledge read, it can prove to be a very good pick.

After wading through an almost infuriating first chapter, I have decided to not continue with this book for now. The author has made too many logical fallacies and sweeping, inaccurate generalizations about philosophy, the society, and individuals that I cannot imagine what he is purportedly going to proselytize to future defenseless readers about our experiences and consciousness in the second chapter. This is the first book that I have decidedly paused reading after making some headways into the book. I may return to it and continue on to the next chapter once I have established more fact-based views of consciousness and experiences from elsewhere rather than having opinions upon more opinions wrapped in a supposedly scientific and carefully reasoned package delivered as if it were an insult to both my eyes and mind.

In this marvelously insightful book, the author attempts to provide us a basis of how our overall living experience can be optimized by exercising control over our consciousness.The author(one of the foremost researchers in this field), presents methods and techniques by which we can effectively control the way we experience things, and how we can achieve 'flow'(optimization) in our everyday experiences, numerous examples have been presented throughout the book that make most of his analogies very easy to grasp and understand.I have personally benefited a lot from this book, because many of the techniques mentioned here have helped me in organizing my own goals, and objectives.All in all, I found this book to be a very satisfying read, and would definitely recommend reading it.

Fantastic book. I liked that he gives many examples of types of experiences that can constitute flow, as well as what is necessary for it: a match between complexity and skill. I would argue that even experiences that do not add complexity to the self can be flow experiences. Being fully present with one's surroundings, for example, can constitute a flow experience, although no special skills are being used and there isn't a great deal of complexity being explored (or is there?). Perhaps most beautiful is the realization that flow experiences are open to all, regardless of financial and material resources.

I rate this book five stars and a half. Actually it makes me want to go back and unrate every other book I gave 5 stars to. Throughout the book I felt Dr. Mihaly was talking about me. It explained a lot to me why I do certain things in certain ways and why I think this way.Dr Mihaly is very deep and very analytical keeping in mind every single detail and what might be going through the readers' mind as well. The book is well written, yet better than all the thoughts and concepts in the book left me overwhelmed! I'd suggest you read it if you think you're crazy or creative or you take great joy out of weird things!

It was a long journey through this one. I was reading it slow and it took me more than six months to finish it. This is also the longest non-fiction I've ever read! I heard about 'flow' years ago; a state where the person is fully immersed in what she/he is doing and enjoys it one hundred percent. The book explains factors that can lead to flow state, and how even simple activities become a pleasurable experience. This is not a guidebook. He has done years of research in this subject. He just summarises his work and leaves it open. We can choose to apply it in our life. There are many case studies to help the reader understand how it works.

Csikszentmihalyi explains, better than anyone else has done to date, what factors contribute to meaning and enjoyment in life. His findings are based on solid research and show that all situations provide opportunities for individuals to cultivate flow for themselves. These autotelic people do so by having goals, discovering purpose, engaging in relevant pursuits, keeping challenge in their life, and being fully involved in the resulting experiences. Pity the soul who never discovers their own source and experience of flow.

I've heard about "Flow" many times before but I never knew it could be applied to everything in life. I heard the book via Audible, hearing Mihaly speaking I would get a bit sleepy but the contents were really nice. I'm looking forward to seeking more and more flow experiences in my life after this book.

Book revolves around experience rather than pleasure 5 things to help us identify flow activities1.Activity which requires our full concentration2.Losing self while doing3.Emerge confident and proud once done4.Lost in the activity without minding time spent 5.No complains on the difficulties faced

What can i say? I didn't get very far before putting this down and never picking it up again. A book my mom bought for me when I was feeling down. Struck me as an overly complicated way of saying you should do what you want in life. Duh.

Really struggled with this (much recommended) book. There are one or two nice tidbits, but the book has just so much other stuff going on - as if the author wants to show off his general knowledge. Not a good read at all. I'd like a recommendation of a better book on this subject.
Beautiful read and a page turner. Impactful on every page and line, with none wasted. A true read. It's lessons were very real and rewarding. :)
